edu.crypto2.transformations
Class MixColumns

java.lang.Object
  edu.crypto2.transformations.MixColumns
All Implemented Interfaces:
Transformation
public class MixColumns
extends java.lang.Object
implements Transformation

Class MixColumns

Task:
To mix State columns (socond part of permutation)
MixColumns transformation takes column by column from AES State and performs matrix multiplication as follows:
.........| 02 03 01 01 |
new = | 01 02 03 01 | * old_column
.........| 01 01 02 03 |
.........| 03 01 01 02 |

Field Summary
 java.lang.String inStr
           
 int Nb
          Nb is always 4 (by FIPS-197), but authors of AES left the space to change something in the future, so we wiil do the same
 
Constructor Summary
MixColumns()
          Dummy constructor.
Task:

Method Summary
 int galoa_mul_tab(int a, int b)
          Galois multiplication
Task:
multiply two numbers using AES (Galois) multiplication
To speed up Galois multiplication, we will use well known formula:
log(x*y)=log(x)*log(y)
x*y=antilog(log(x)*log(y))
and already calculated subresults stored in ltable and atable

Method Detail

galoa_mul_tab

public int galoa_mul_tab(int a,
                         int b)
Galois multiplication
Task:
multiply two numbers using AES (Galois) multiplication
To speed up Galois multiplication, we will use well known formula:
log(x*y)=log(x)*log(y)
x*y=antilog(log(x)*log(y))
and already calculated subresults stored in ltable and atable

Parameters:
a - (int/byte 0..255)
b - (int/byte 0..255)
Returns:
result of multiplication

InitializeState

public void InitializeState()
initialize_State

Fills State array with initial values taken from inStr.

Specified by:
InitializeState in interface Transformation
Parameters:
inStr - String inStr - 32 alphanumercis with hex values (16 bytes)

TransformState

public void TransformState()
MixColumns.TransformState

MixColumns transformation takes column by column from AES State and performs matrix multiplication as follows:
.........| 02 03 01 01 |
new = | 01 02 03 01 | * old_column
.........| 01 01 02 03 |
.........| 03 01 01 02 |
